Hi Jeff,

I'm glad you enjoyed the paper and thanks for taking the tim=
e to consider its implications. I'm happy to answer your questions. 

1) Fo=
r clarity, the assumption directly quoted from the paper is only about whet=
her evolvability is heritabile; in general, I think that assumption often h=
olds and is not what you are disputing.

What you are questioning is whethe=
r the mechanisms towards evolvability we demonstrate in the paper have any =
real-world effect or if they are simply overridden by optimization pressure=
 against evolvability (through pressure to converge upon some local fitness=
 peak, which might select against any deviation). This is an interesting qu=
estion, open to speculation. Ultimately, I do not think the answer is abund=
antly clear either way; if in each niche there was some sort of 'race' betw=
een optimization and evolvability, those individuals diverging through nich=
es faster than optimization tamed them would yet gain from the founder effe=
ct -- of course if the taming pressure was so strong that no one could ever=
 escape you are right, the founder effect would be stymied and no new niche=
s would ever be discovered. However, because nature seems quite good at spr=
eading through niches, this does not seem to be the case. Also, because nic=
hes in nature are not purely static any pressure against evolvability from =
fitness optimization may be further mitigated.

But even asking if the mech=
anisms for evolvability in the paper are generally impeded interestingly hi=
ghlights that an important contribution of the paper may be to demonstratat=
e that increasing evolvability may be the background null hypothesis, which=
 is an interesting shift. In other words, your argument suggests that the c=
urrent question of 'why is evolvability so widespread,' may move towards 'w=
hat forces impede the innate tendency towards evolvability'? And one potent=
ial such impeding force is given by the fitness-optimization argument you m=
ake. But even if fitness pressure does turn out to often impede the non-ada=
ptive mechanisms for evolvability from the paper, it is still interesting n=
onetheless that the drive towards evolvability may be more fundamental than=
 previously thought. 

In my mind, it seems a much more elegant explanation=
 if evolvability is fundamental and that is the reason it seems to increase=
, rather than that it is fundamental, but is opposed by one type of adaptiv=
e pressure, and only enabled by additional specific forms of adaptive press=
ure (because you then still need an explanation for why evolvability appear=
s to have increased). Of course, elegance can be deceiving, and overall my =
intuition that fitness-pressure does not dominate the mechanisms we show in=
 the paper likely reflects my novelty-search influenced perspective: That e=
volution as a whole is more a story of discovering a growing diversity of w=
ays to make a living than it is of static optimization towards local optima=
.

More concretely, to address your concerns about mutation rates, I think =
it is first important to distinguish between *genotypic* mutation rates and=
 the resulting *phenotypic* variability such mutation generates. In the abs=
tract model in the paper, evolvability is encoded as the probability for an=
 organism to change its niche, which is not generally the same as a genotyp=
ic mutation rate (although for simplicity they are are equated in that mode=
l). In the concrete ER models, for example, evolvability is an implicit fun=
ction of the ANN's architecture, which is perhaps more similar to nature, w=
here a genotypic mutation's phenotypic effect often results from a complex =
developmental process. So even if mutation rates are dialed down low by opt=
imization pressure, those mutations may yet cause significant phenotypic ef=
fect; and perhaps some of that significant phenotypic effect might be neutr=
al with respect to reproductive success (for example, one can imagine that =
some heritable differences in human height might yet have negligible impact=
s on biological success). In this way, phenotypic variability may still be =
high even if mutation rates are driven down, and differences in such variab=
ility may still enable more evolvable lineages to be more likely to found n=
ew niches.

So I think while it may be true that pressure to optimize fitne=
ss in nature may sometimes oppose evolvability, it is not clear that this w=
ill often dominate evolvability, that static optimization is the predominan=
t paradigm for evolution within niches, or that selection for decreased mut=
ation rates need always select against phenotypic variability. 

2) It is t=
rue that there is no consensus on how to define evolvability; however I'd a=
rgue that there is a growing shift in the literature (or at least a growing=
 openness) towards considering evolvability more generally, in terms of phe=
notypic variability, and not only limited to considering evolvability in te=
rms of adaptive changes. Whereas measuring phenotypic variability can be so=
mewhat context-independent, tying evolvability to adaptation means that evo=
lvability becomes dependent upon particular situations, and that what is ev=
olvable today may not be evolvable tomorrow. I would argue that a complex a=
nimal like a human is evolvable in some sort of absolute way. It may also b=
e that a person's preference for definition may reflect whether one sees ev=
olution more as an optimization process or as a discovery process.

As to h=
ow adopting a more adaptive measure would affect the interpretation of the =
paper -- it is not clear. The adaptive style of definition doesn't seem to =
quite apply to the models in the paper because there is no way to outcompet=
e other organisms within particular niches. I suppose that if you mandate t=
hat evolvability must relate to adaptive changes, then it may become imposs=
ible to consider models without adaptive pressure in them, because that def=
inition only makes sense then with some sort of adaptive context. This seem=
s strange to me, it doesn't seem like evolvability should change with the w=
eather.

3) It is true that the organisms can mutate in any direction and t=
hat oftentimes an evolvable organism will land end up near the starting nic=
he; but the bias is that more often than not the far-flung ones will be the=
 more evolvable ones. The reason you don't see some hiccups in Fig 3. is th=
at it is averaged over many runs, as is Fig. 2. Any one run would likely ha=
ve some of the variance you are describing.

I hope you find these answers =
interesting, I enjoy thinking about the sorts of questions you've raised, i=
n particular, how fitness pressure may interact with the evolvability mecha=
nisms in the paper. Thanks again for taking the time to read the paper and =
raise these well-informed questions.

Best,
Joel

> Hello Joel and Ken,
> 
> Congrats on=
 the excellent paper. I enjoyed it. 
> 
> Congrats also on the nice press c=

1bc7d-282027325
> 
> (nice office Ken)
> 
> I have a three questions, two h=
igher-level and one pedantic.
> 
> 1) You write: "Thus if the assumption of=
 evolvability's heritability holds, then such founder effects in establishi=
ng new niches may yield a persistent bias towards increasing evolvability =
=96 even in the absence of adaptive competition between organisms."
> 
> My=
 guess is that this assumption doesn't hold across many generations in the =
scenario you outline. Your model, especially the limited capacity model, aw=
ards permanent winner status to the founder (if I understand it correctly),=
 but obviously that does not happen in nature. In nature, once a niche is f=
ounded, there is no pressure (for those orgs staying in the niche) to retai=
n their evolvability (assuming a relatively static environment). As my muta=
tion rates paper shows (http://goo.gl/I8r40), once a population is on a loc=
al fitness peak there is a strong pressure to lower the mutation rate (whic=
h in your model is the same thing as evolvability). Offspring of the founde=
r with lower mutRates/evolvability would have higher average fitness than o=
ffsprings with the original, elevated mutRate/evolvability, thus leading to=
 a lowering of mutation rates/evolvability across generations. If that is r=
ight, it would erase this founder effect and eliminate the appearance of ev=
olvability even when averaging across niches, no? In other words, you'd onl=
y see this elevation in newly occupied niches, which would be a small fract=
ion of the total number of niches after millennia. In short, while I agree =
with this clever demonstration that evolvability can increase without selec=
tion, it could be the case that selection itself eliminates this sort of ev=
olvability effect, leaving us still searching for how nature generates and =
maintains evolvability. You could test this by trying your same experiments=
 in the abstract model, but on a rugged fitness landscape (e.g. Rastrigin),=
 and I'm confident you'd see the mutation rate/evolvability go to near zero=
 (that's effectively the exact experiment I did in my PLoS Comp Bio paper).=
 That result would jive with your belief that selection may actually preclu=
de evolvability and be a hinderance to open-ended evolution, but it may als=
o mean that the effect you point out is not a major explanation of evolvabi=
lity in the natural world where selection is a powerful force. I hope I don=
't come across as someone trying to diminish the importance of your work; i=
nstead I am trying to understand how far I can extrapolate it to the natura=
l world. 
> 
> 2) You repeatedly mention that you are using one of many def=
initions of evolvability, defining it as synonymous with phenotypic variabi=
lity. I got the impression that you were arguing for one definition of evol=
vability from a set of common ones, perhaps even a less common one. I usual=
ly think of evolvability as certain kinds of phenotypic variability (e.g. e=
volution produces the subset of variants that have a higher average fitness=
 than the entire set of possible variants). What would the implications for=
 your paper be if you adopted that (I believe more common) definition of ev=
olvability? Are there other major definitions of evolvability that you enco=
untered in your literature search? If so, does adopting them change the int=
erpretation of your paper?
> 
> 3) Here's the pedantic question. In your ab=
stract model (not the limited capacity model, the unlimited one), I assume =
that mutations can move an org one step in any direction, including back to=
ward the center. Given that, shouldn't a higher mutation rate just mean a l=
arger variance around the origin? Random walks, after all, still have an av=
erage location of their starting point. If so, I agree that the  far-flung =
niches would disproportionately have high evolvability, but I would also ex=
pect to see greater variance in evolvability in the central niches than the=
 distant niches...but that's the opposite of Fig. 3. If each organism is on=
 a random walk, and higher evolvability means a faster pace, then you would=
 have lots of these faster organisms traversing back and forth across the c=
enter too, but you don't see any of those orgs in Fig. 3. I am sure I am mi=
sunderstanding something, and it is probably trivial, but I just wanted to =
ask in case my misunderstanding is making me not fully appreciate your work=
. 
> 
> Congratulations again. I'm still thinking about all of the implicat=
ions of the paper. 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
